def: Away from the apex of a shell toward the base.
Full of small bulgings; resembling the kernel in a nut.
Very sharply pointed, as the teeth on the radula of some snails.
Gradually tapering to a point, as the spire of some shells.
Sharp or pointed, as the spire of a shell, or the lip of a shell.
Toward the apex of a shell (<--> abapical).
Next to the central object, as the lateral teeth on the lingual membrane.
With overlapping whorls or with a suture tightly pressed to the previous whorl (preferred to the term appressed).
To bring in; when relating to a vessel or duct, indicating that it brings in its contents.
Shaped like an amoeba, a small animalcule.
With the ligament on both sides of the umbones.
A likeness between two objects when otherwise they are totally different, as the wing of a bird and the wing of a butterfly.
Bowed or bent in a curve.
Tightly coiled, as some spiral shells.
Act of converting one substance into another, as the changing of food-stuffs into living bodies.
Long and slender, as in some shells.
A hardened and raised bunch, as the callus on the columella of some shells.
Resembling a canal, as the deep sutures in some shells.
Formed of cross-bars, as the longitudinal and spiral lines which cross in some shells.
Containing the heart and placed near the umb'ones of the shell.
Tail-like, or with a tail-like appendage.
Grooved or formed like a channel.
Formed of chitin, as the radulas of gastropods.
A lash; used to designate the hairs on the mantle, gills, etc.
A part connecting two other parts, as a muscle connecting two parts of the body, or a nerve connecting two ganglia.
Capable of being contracted or drawn in, as the tentacle of a snail.
Bulged out, as the whorls of some snails.
Horn-like, as the opercula of some gastropods.
Cut off, as the apex of some shells.
With spiral and longitudinal lines intersecting, as the sculpture of some shells.
Bent downward, as the last whorl in some snails.
With points or nodules resembling teeth, as the aperture of some snails.
Flattened, as the spire in some snails.
Expanded in all directions, as the aperture of a shell.
Having the sexes in two individuals, one male and one female.
The farthest part from an object.
A pouch or hole, as the pouch containing the radula, or that containing the dart in helices.
In a state of torpor or sleep.
The back. In gastropods the opposite to the aperture.
The outer cusp on the teeth of the radula.
Without teeth or folds, as the aperture in some gastropods.
Drawn out, as the spire of a shell.
The inner cusp on the teeth of the radula.
With even, unbroken edges, as the aperture of some shells.
A portion of the vas deferens which becomes modified into a tube-like organ and is continued beyond the apex of the penis; it frequently bears a blind duct, or flagellum.
All tissues bounding a free surface.
Equally spaced, as the spiral lines on some snail shells.
Worn away, as the epidermis on some shells.
Hollowed out, as the columella of some snails.
Referring to the siphon which carries out the waste matter of the body.
The outer skeleton; all shells are exoskeletons.
Spread out, as the lip of some shells.
Animals with a flagellum or lash.
Formed in a series of curves or turnings, as the columella in some shells.
Thick in the middle and tapering at each end.
Like jelly, as the eggs of some mollusks.
Very much rounded, as the whorls in some snails.
A female mollusk with ovaries distended with young.
Relating to the windpipe or palate. In mollusks, referring to the innermost part of the aperture.
Having the sexes united in the same individual.
The act of hibernating or going to sleep for the winter months.
Covered with hairs, as some snails.
Having the same position or value, as the wing of a bird and of a bat.
Marked by a furrow, as the impressed spiral lines on some gastropod shells.
Leaned or bent over, as the apex in some snails.
Turned in, as the teeth of some snails.
One part bending into another, as the tentacles of some land snails.
Capable of being inverted, or drawn in, as the eye-peduncles of a land snail.
With a more or less sharp projection at the periphery.
Consisting of plates or scales laid over each other.
Shaped like a half moon, as the aperture in some shells.
Relating to the apparatus for masticating food. In snails, the jaws and radula.
Middle, as the middle tooth on the radula.
The middle cusp on the teeth of the radula.
Having the sexes united in the same individual.
Made up of many lobes or projections, as the cusps on some radulae.
Consisting of many whorls, as some fresh-water snails.
The second stage of the embryonic shell, as the glochidium.
Nicked or indented, as the anterior canal of some gastropods.
The first part or beginning, as the apex in a gastropod shell.
In the form of a reversed cone.
Slanting, as the aperture of some shells when not parallel to the longitudinal axis.
Reversed ovate, as some shells when the diameter is greater near the upper than at the lower part.
Dull or blunt, as the apex of some gastropods.
An organized being, or living object made up of organs.
Shaped like an egg, but with a somewhat conic apex, as some gastropods.
Bringing forth young in an egg which is hatched after it is laid.
A pouch in which the eggs or embryos are contained.
In this case the young are formed in an egg but are hatched inside the parent.
Covered with many little bulgings or pimples.
Having the same relative distance in all parts, as when the spiral lines in univalve shells are the same distance apart all the way around.
Shaped like a flattened-out cone, as an Ancylus.
Open and spreading, as the aperture in some gastropods.
Only slightly spiral, as some opercula.
Like the teeth of a comb, as the gills of some mollusks.
Supported on a stem or stalk, as the eyes of land snails.
Transparent or clear, as the shells of some snails; e. g. Vitrea.
The whorl before the last in gastropod shells.
The epidermal covering of some shells.
Very narrowly open, as the umbilicus in some snails.
Branched like a feather, as the gills of some mollusks.
Flat and orb-like, as some snails.
Relating to the side of a body.
A network of vessels, as the form of the lungs in snails.
The nearest end of an object.
A throb, as the throbbing of the heart.
Like a pupa; one of the stages in the development of an insect.
Covered with pustules or little pimples.
Having the form of a pyramid.
Bent backward, as the lip in some snails.
Resembling a network, as when the longitudinal and spiral lines cross in a snail.
Capable of being drawn in, as the eye peduncles in land snails.
Spiral lines on a snail shell which run parallel with the sutures.
Having four sides, the angles being oblique.
Four-sided, but two of the sides being longer than the others.
Provided with a very small hole or crack, as some snails in which the umbilicus is very narrowly open.
In the form of a rostrum.
Rough or wrinkled, as parts of some shells.
Somewhat like a sac, or composed of sac-like parts.
Produced or deposited from the blood or glands, as the shell material in mollusks.
Half round or circular, as the aperture in some snails.
Half toothed, as the parietal wall in some land snails.
Notched, like the teeth on a saw.
Attached without a stem, as the eyes in some water snails.
Ridged, as the whorls in some snails.
Having the aperture on the left side.
Curved in and out, as the edge of some bivalves and the lips of some snails.
semi-tubular extension of the aperture of the shell through which the siphon is extended when the animal is active
In the form of a spatula, a flat-bladed instrument used by druggists in pulverizing drugs.
Wound about a central cavity, as the whorls of snails.
Alike on both sides or uniform in all parts.
Half unconscious or asleep, as a snail during hibernation.
Not quite transparent; light is seen through the thin edges of the object.
Objects may be seen through the substance.
Referring to the form of a shell when it is wider than high.
Divided into three parts, as the foot of some snails.
Having the end cut off squarely.
Covered with tubercles or rounded knobs.
Having the form of a top.
Having the form of a tower.
Having the form of a tower.
Having an opening in the base of the shell.
Having the shell composed of a single piece, as a snail.
Containing or made up of blood vessels.
Swollen or inflated on the ventral side.
